title: After Two Years on the Market, Beverly Hills Megamansion Ups Asking Price by $20 Million
text:
Opus, the lavish Beverly Hills megamansion that catapulted onto the market in 2017 with a nine-figure price tag and a garish promotional video, has just increased its asking price by almost $20 million—after two years of price cuts.



The gilded spec house upped its price to $79.9 million last week, a $19.9 million increase from the $59.9 million it had been asking since May, listing records show.

The mansion initially hit the market asking $100 million.

The seven-bedroom home, being offered by producer-turned-developer Nile Niami, is in the swanky Beverly Hills neighborhood of Trousdale Estates. Mr. Niami could not be reached for comment.



Designed by architect Paul McClean, it sits on one acre and spans 20,000 square feet, according to the listing with Rayni and Branden Williams of Hilton & Hyland, who did not immediately respond to a request for comment.



The mansion has a wine cellar, two swimming pools, a car museum, a screening room and is described in the listing as a “modern space station.”



The increased asking price stands out in the Los Angeles luxury market where many of the highest priced listings have received sizable price cuts.

The Los Angeles property dubbed Chartwell—also the most expensive home on the market in the U.S.—got significantly less expensive in June, after chopping $50 million from its asking price, taking its price tag down to $195 million from a whopping $245 million.



At the beginning of the year, the former estate of the late film industry titan, Lew Wasserman, hit the market for $125 million. By March, the price had been trimmed to $97.5 million.



And a 12-bedroom Bel Air mansion with its own helipad and a candy wall is currently asking $150 million, far below the $250 million it was first being shopped for in 2017.



A wave of development has left the market oversaturated with high-priced megamansions, and there aren’t enough buyers to go around, according to the Wall Street Journal.
